Award.AwardTitle: Anchoring High School Students in Real-life Issues that Integrate STEM Content and Literacy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The STEM Literacy Project sets out to support student learning through developing teacher expertise in collaborative integration of STEM in student writing and literacy skills development. Facilitated by teachers, students will read, discuss, and then write about real-world STEM scenarios, such as water quality or health. The project will build on and research a professional development program first developed through a state-supported literacy program for middle and high school science and math teachers to improve literacy-integrated instruction. The goals of this project include the following: (1) Create a community of practice that recognizes high school teachers as content experts; (2) Implement high quality professional development for teachers on STEM/Literacy integration; (3) Develop assessments based on STEM and literacy standards that inform instruction; and (4) Conduct rigorous research to understand the impact of the professional development. The program is aligned with state and national standards for college and career readiness. Project resources will be widely shared through a regularly updated project website (stemliteracyproject.org), conference presentations, and publications reaching researchers, developers, and educators. These resources will include scenario-based assessment tools and instructional materials.

Through the integration of STEM content and literacy, the project will study the ways teachers implement project practices integrating literacy activities into STEM learning. Teachers will facilitate instruction using scenarios that present students with everyday, STEM-related issues, presented as scenarios, that they read and write about. After reading and engaging with math and science content, students will write a source-based argument in which they state a claim, support the claim with evidence from the texts, and explain the multiple perspectives on the issue. These scenarios provide students with agency as they craft an argument for an audience, such as presenting to a city council, a school board, or another group of stakeholders. Project research will use a mixed methods design. Based on the work completed through the initial designs and development of scenario-based assessments, rubrics, and scoring processes, the project will study the impact on instruction and student learning. Using a triangulation design convergence model, findings will be compared and contrasted in order for the data to inform one another and lead to further interpretation of the data. project will analyze the features of STEM content learning after program-related instruction. Data collected will include pre-post student scenario-based writing; pre-post interviews of up to 40 students each year; pre-post teacher interviews; and teacher-created scenario-based assessments and supporting instructional materials. Student learning reflected in the assessments paired with student and teacher interview responses will provide a deeper understanding of this approach of integrating STEM and literacy. The use of discourse analysis methods will allow growth in content learning to be measured through language use. Project research will build knowledge in the field concerning how participation in teacher professional development integrating STEM content in literacy practices impacts teacher practices and student learning.

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by pre-K-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anchoring High School Students in Real-life Issues that Integrate STEM Content and Literacy

 

In this Impact Study, the University of Missouri—in partnership with Mid-Missouri public schools, the University of Missouri - St. Louis, University of Central Missouri, and Wright State University— implemented a professional development program to help teachers re-envision STEM literacy by integrating science content with literacy skills. STEM and literacy connections are complex as traditional education practices isolate content areas and seldom provide opportunities to intentionally integrate disciplines.  In addition, students need to see how what they are learning applies to real-world problems (Zeidler & Sadler, 2008). The STEM Literacy Project supports student learning through developing teacher expertise in collaborative integration of literacy across science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). 

 

Professional Learning in the STEM Literacy Project

During the three years of the project, teachers were provided with synchronous zoom sessions, in-person professional learning days three times a year, and regular asynchronous reading, reflecting, and responding through online platforms.   The evaluation surveys completed after each PD session, ranked the quality of the PD as highly beneficial to the teachers’ learning and their implementation of literacy practices into their STEM classrooms. Teachers in the program represented rural and urban areas spread throughout Missouri, which allowed the teachers to learn from one another about their differences and similarities of their school and community contexts. By integrating STEM content areas with literacy, teachers developed a strong community in which they learned from one another and developed as education leaders, many of them presenting at regional and national content area conferences as a result. 

 

Recent sessions included education faculty from the university sharing evidence-based instructional strategies such as "MCTM Math in Action – Exploring the viral spread of disease and disinformation" by Dr. Sam Otten and practitioner teachers sharing highlights from the resources they developed and  implemented as part of the STEM Literacy learning. In addition, participant teachers reviewed student work to share with one another strengths, learning, and areas for growth. 

Teachers' responses were overwhelmingly positive (100% of teachers either strongly agree or agree on 5-point Likert scale PD evaluation questions). Open-ended comments verified their responses. Some of the positive remarks included the following:

  • I get so much (ideas, inspiration, validation) from hearing and seeing other teachers' presentations and learning from them.  I also appreciate the resources and texts that were shared.
  • Love the reading and writing strategies because they were so adaptable.
  • Storylining- I have heard of them but never used them. Was happy to learn more about them and how they integrate content. Equity- made me reflect on my own practices.
  • Love hearing ideas from creative teachers/educators.
  • So many teachers surviving the challenges and still implementing new STEM Lit ideas.
  • Teacher collaboration with awesome teachers! Love having this network!

 

Scenario-based Assessments

During the program, teachers developed and implemented Scenario-based Assessments (SBAs) that aligned with the types of assessments used for statewide tests and that included reading and writing tasks within a problem-based/issue-based scenario. Such assessments engaged students in reading the scenario, working with evidence, and drafting an argument that included complex and real-life, socio-scientific issues. Teachers and students found these assessments to be meaningful and students demonstrated improvement in their ability to use evidence and reasoning to support a claim. The analysis of the student scores on the SBAs suggest that the teachers’ implementation of a literacy-based approach to STEM teaching, focused on argumentation around SSI, resulted in a significant improvement in their ability to use Claim-Evidence-Reasoning. 

 

Reaching Beyond STEM Literacy Project to Other Teachers

Our goal was to study the impact of this integrated professional learning model to use in broader outreach such as the Missouri Writing Projects Network (MWPN - sites of the National Writing Project) and the state’s Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE). During the three years of the project, program teachers were involved as co-facilitators for both DESE and MWPN professional learning sessions, reaching hundreds of teachers throughout the state of Missouri, and scaling the model of Professional Development that they experienced in the Stem Literacy Project.  

 

This work is significant due to the vital role that literacy practices play in improving student learning while also providing students with stronger communication skills. A challenge is that teachers often do not feel confident in their own reading and writing practices, and they may not have the background in teaching literacy practices in their content areas. Today’s pre-service education programs are adding requirements to address reading and writing in the content areas for future secondary teachers; however, veteran in-service teachers may not have had a strong grounding in literacy. Working with educators from STEM disciplines and literacy/English education, this professional development opportunity strengthens content knowledge, pedagogy, and student learning.
